Graphical abstract Described is the transformation of ethanol into 1-butanol, acetaldehyde and other products by the Guerbet reaction (GR) over mixed metal oxides (MMOs) as catalysts. The MMOs, in which Mg2+ was partially (20 mol%) substituted by Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+, were obtained from hydrotalcite precursors and the reactions conducted in a fixed bed flow reactor. EPR was used to observe oxygen vacancies after the catalytic reactions, which may be related to the ethanol reactivity due to the basicity enhancement of the catalyst. Carbon deposition, mostly filamentous, was observed in all catalysts and a trend between the metal-carbon bond energy and the percentage of deposited carbon was established. This correlation and the catalyst product distribution can be useful to tailor new catalysts. Using four parameters, ethanol conversion, 1-butanol and side-product selectivities and percentage of carbon deposition, Zn20MMO proved to be the best choice for GR. Keywords Ethanol Guerbet reaction First-row transition metals 1-Butanol 1 Introduction One of the challenges of twenty-first-century chemistry is discovering new synthetic routes, catalysts and industrial processes to try and obtain raw chemicals and fuels, which nowadays are almost exclusively derived from petrol [1–4]. From this perspective, ethanol has been the choice starting material for the aforementioned purposes since it has an intrinsically renewable nature (obtained by fermentation/distillation of sugars from vegetables) and there is already infra-structure installed for high-volume production. These enable it to be a new renewable carbon source [5–8]. There are two main approaches to using ethanol as a starting material for obtaining raw chemicals. The first one is the ethanol reforming reaction, aiming to produce hydrogen (H2) [9,10]. The second approach is the ethanol condensation reaction (the Guerbet reaction (GR)), aiming to produce raw chemicals with long-chain carbon compounds, mostly alcohols (1-butanol, hexanol, octanol) and aldehydes, which are the reactive intermediates for GR [11–17]. Although the products from both approaches, hydrogen and condensed products, are interesting from the economic and environmental point of view, the routes are competitive. Thus, the catalyst and the reaction parameters must be tuned to favor the desired route. The ethanol condensation mechanism was proposed by Guerbet at the beginning of the twenty-century [16,17] and has been studied in detail since then. The GR is always catalyzed, and many classes of catalysts, homo- and heterogenous, have already been proposed. [18–30]. Long-chain carbon alcohols can be obtained by ethanol dehydrogenation into acetaldehyde, which reacts with another acetaldehyde molecule in an aldol condensation reaction. The condensation product (crotonaldehyde) is obtained by a dehydration reaction and the final product, 1-butanol, is formed by the hydrogenation of the olefinic double bond and the aldehyde. The presence of acetaldehyde in the reaction medium allows the formation of side products such as ethers and esters. Focusing on the GR products, the simplified mechanism is depicted in Fig. 1 . As depicted in Fig. 1, the acetaldehyde reactivity is the key-step for GR, since it can give rise to esters and to CO and CH4. These reforming reaction products present a well-established route to carbon deposition over the catalyst (nanostructured and amorphous carbon through acetaldehyde decomposition (1), methane dehydrogenation (2), and the Boudouard reaction (3) that can poison the catalyst [31–41]. Thus, the control of carbon deposition is a key-issue for long-term stability of the catalysts. Due to the nature of the coupling reaction, the catalyst must perform both dehydrogenation and hydrogenation reactions. This dual behavior can be obtained by using mixed metal oxide (MMO) catalysts, which have already shown to be active in methanol, ethanol and butanol catalytic transformations [20,42–47]. The MMOs are a large class of materials synthesized by many different routes [48–50]. Our research group has been using hydrotalcite-like materials (HTC), composed primarily by Mg2+ and Al3+, as a precursor of MMOs, due to its simple synthetic route, reproducibility and the possibility of replacing Mg2+ or Al3+ ions by transition metals or lanthanide ions [18,29,43,51,52]. The main research focus is the substitution of Mg2+ ions by divalent ions of the first-row transition metal series due to their lower cost and higher abundance, both being essential prerequisites for the development of new catalysts for upgrading ethanol into added-value products. Also, there are no reports in the literature comparing the reactivity of a series of MMOs in which Mg2+ was partially substituted by divalent metal ions of the first-row transition metal series and the catalyst behavior of these materials in GR. Here, the synthesis and characterization of a series of HTCs containing Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+ as precursors of MMOs employed as catalysts for GR is described. The reactions were carried out in a fixed bed flow reactor (FBFR), operating at 450 °C, at atmospheric pressure and the distribution of the products by class (alcohols, aldehydes, ethers, and esters) was observed. The temporal behaviors for the main reaction products were compared for each catalyst. The catalysts were also characterized after the catalytic runs, aiming to gain insights into the catalyst stability, reactivity, and carbon deposition. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts synthesis and characterization The hydrotalcites (HTCs), which are the mixed metal oxide (MMO) precursors, were synthesized using the co-precipitation method as described in the literature, using an Mg2+/Al3+ ratio of 3:1 [48,49,53]. The Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (99 %), Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (98 %), Na2CO3 (99.5 %), NaOH (97 %), FeCl2⋅4H2O (98 %), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (>98 %), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (> 97 %) Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (99 %), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98 %) salts were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Deionized water was utilized in all synthetic procedures and solutions. For the HTC synthesis, 0.2 mols of Na2CO3 was dissolved into 120 mL of water and heated at 60 °C under stirring. The solution pH was corrected to 10 using 1.0 M solution of NaOH. In 160 mL of water, 0.096 mols of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 0.024 mols of the desired first-row transition metal nitrate and 0.04 mols of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O were dissolved and slowly dropped into Na2CO3 solution, checking the pH and keeping it at 10 using the 1.0 M NaOH solution. After the addition of the nitrate solutions, the resulting slurry was aged for 24 h in oven at 60 °C. The resulting material was filtered, and exhaustively washed with deionized water, until the washing solution reached pH 7. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h, powdered and kept in vacuum desiccator. The same procedure was utilized to synthetize the reference material, without magnesium substitution (using 0.12 mols of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and 0.04 mols of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O). The HTCs were labeled as M20HTC, in which M represents the transition metal cation that substituted the Mg2+, 20 means 20 mol% of substitution, and HTC means hydrotalcite and characterized by X-Ray diffraction (XRD). The HTCs were calcined at 450 °C for 5 h under an atmosphere of air to obtain the MMOs. The MMOs were labeled as M20MMO and MMO following the same labeling procedure as described before. The MMOs, before and after the reaction, were characterized by XRD, surface area by the BET method, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The full description of the equipment and methods employed for HTC and MMO characterization, before and after the catalytic reactions, is described in the Supplementary Material. 2.2 Fixed bed flow reactor (FBFR) The research group developed the FBFR employed in the catalytic reactions. It was composed of a Jasco pump (model PU-980), an oven equipped with a heater/thermocouple controlled by a Watlow micro processed based auto-tuning temperature controller (model series-96). The reactor column was machined using stainless steel (316 L alloy), with dimensions of 12.0 × 1.0 × 0.5 cm (L x O.D. x I.D.). The column was coupled with a stainless-steel condenser in which cold water (4 °C) continuously circulated to condense the outcoming products. The condenser was coupled to a rubber septum glass flask to collect the products. The flask has a gas output, connected to a graduated cylinder to measure the gas volume generated during the reaction. The reactor scheme is presented in Fig. S1. 2.3 Catalytic reactions All the reactions were carried out using ethanol 95 % (5 % of water) pumped (flow of 0.2 mL/min) through a heated 15 cm stainless steel tube, which allowed ethanol to vaporize before entering the reactor column head. No carrier gas was employed. The reactor column was filled with a mixture of 0.3 g of M20MMOs and 1.4 g of silica to disperse the catalyst homogeneously. After packing the column and before heating the reactor, the ethanol flow was turned on and the volume was checked before starting the heating ramp (20 °C/min). Once the temperature reached 450 °C, the catalysts were activated in situ by ethanol, which corresponds to the first 30 min of reaction until the products reached a plateau. The collector flasks were changed every 30 min in a total of 6 h of reaction. The flasks containing the condensed products were kept in a freezer (−20 °C) until the analysis. 2.4 Products analysis and quantification The reaction product identification and quantification were carried out using a GC Clarus 500 gas chromatograph coupled with a 600 T mass spectrometer detector (Perkin Elmer). Chromatographic conditions: He as carrier gas (2.0 mL/min), injector temperature at 250 °C, injection volume of 1 μL, BD-EN14103 column (30 m x0.320 mm x 0.25 μm, Agilent), temperature program: 40 °C for 10 min, 10 °C/min until 160 °C, 2 °C/min until 180 °C, 10 °C/min until 240 °C holding 2 min. Mass spectrometer conditions: an m/z ratio ranging from 40 to 300 and an ionization energy of 70 eV. Before GC–MS analysis, the samples were prepared adding 20 μL of the collected solution, 10 μL of ethyl dodecanoate (internal standard) and 970 μL of MS grade methanol. The products were quantified by the correlation factor determined for a series of classes of compounds (alcohols, ketones, ethers, esters, five-member rings, six-member aromatics) as described in a previous paper [43]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The catalyst precursors, HTCs, were characterized by XRD. All the materials presented the XRD pattern characteristic of HTCs with seven peaks (Fig. S2), indicating that the partial substitution of Mg2+ by Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ was successfully achieved [43,48,51]. Also, the calculation of the crystallographic parameters for each material (Table S1) indicates that incorporating the above-mentioned ions in the hydrotalcite structure did not drastically change the hydrotalcite structure. After the HTC calcination at 450 °C for 5 h, the materials were converted into MMOs. The MMOs were characterized by XRD, indicating the complete change in the material structure, since the characteristic 7-peak pattern of the HTC was replaced by the 3-peak characteristic patterns of the MMOs (Fig. S3) [43]. The MMOs were also characterized by surface area, and acidity and basicity measurements. The surface area of the MMOs is coherent with the values reported in the literature [26,28,29,43] of around 100 m2/g (Table S2), with Zn20MMO being the catalyst with the highest surface area (132.9 ± 1.4 m2/g) and Co20MMO that with the lowest (92.6 ± 1.4 m2/g). Analyzing the values of acidity and basicity and comparing them with the reference material (MMO), the partial substitution of Mg2+ by Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ induced a decrease in the basicity and an increase of the acidity values (Table S2). These changes are important to the reactivity of the catalysts, since it is already reported in the literature that the balance between the acidity and basicity in the catalyst is crucial for its bifunctional behavior, which is important for the GR. 3.1.1 Ethanol consumption and catalyst stability Aiming to investigate the catalyst stabilities and the ethanol consumption, all the catalysts and the reference material were submitted to reactions in the FBFR at 450 °C for 6 h and the ethanol consumption followed by GC–MS. The results are summarized in Fig. 2 . As can be observed in Fig. 2, after 60 min of reaction, all the catalysts reached the maximum ethanol consumption. However, values were distinct depending on the metal substitution, the highest being for Zn20MMO (85 %) and the lowest for Fe20MMO (47 %). Analyzing the temporal behavior of ethanol consumption for each catalyst, the maximum values for ethanol consumption were not maintained during the 6 h period for all MMOs tested. At this point, it is possible to divide the catalysts into two distinct groups: MMO, Ni20MMO, and Zn20MMO were the ones that presented a small decrease in the ethanol consumption and then kept it constant; Fe20MMO, Co20MMO, and Cu20MMO had the ethanol consumption gradually decreased, indicating that these catalysts were deactivated during the reaction period of 6 h. It is important to mention that Cu20MMO reached 95 % of ethanol consumption with 30 min of reaction but lost almost 50 % of its activity after 6 h (47 %). 3.2 Product distribution All the catalysts were able to produce four classes of compounds in the following order of abundance: alcohols, aldehydes, ethers and esters. The abundance of each class depended on divalent transition metal ions incorporated in the MMOS. Fig. 3 A shows the product distribution by class for each catalyst, and Fig. 3B shows the main products for each class. As shown in Fig. 3, Ni20MMO is the catalyst that produces more alcohols, followed by Cu20MMO, MMO, and Zn20MMO. For all catalysts, the major alcohol obtained is 1-butanol (>95 %) with small amounts of 1-hexanol (mostly for the Cu20MMO catalyst). Considering the aldehydes, the catalysts Co20MMO and Zn20MMO produce almost twice as much than the other catalysts, acetaldehyde (ca. 75 %) being the major aldehyde obtained, followed by butyraldehyde (ca. 25 %). The third class of products, ethers, was higher for the MMO and Fe20MMO and lower for the Zn20MMO, diethyl ether being the most abundant product for this class, followed by butyl ethyl ether. Finally, the last class in terms of abundance were esters, which contributed to less than 15 % of the product composition for all MMOs, ethyl acetate and ethyl butanoate being the major ones. Note that no esters were observed in the product distribution for the reference MMO. 3.3 Product temporal behavior The selectivities for the main products of each class (1-butanol, acetaldehyde, diethyl ether and ethyl acetate) were followed by 6 h for all catalysts as shown in Fig. 4 . The other identified and quantified products for each catalyst are shown in Tables S3–S8. In general, the four products mentioned above reached maximum production in the range from 30 to 60 min. This period is coherent with the maximum ethanol consumption observed in Fig. 2 and may be explained by initial ethanol reforming over the fresh catalyst surface, generating metal hydrides and hydrogen. After 60 min, the main product temporal behavior changed according to the product and catalyst. Taking into account 1-butanol, the target product for ethanol GR, only the Fe20MMO catalyst diminished the production, while the catalysts MMO, Ni20MMO, and Zn20MMO kept constant with selectivities of 38.5, 46.2 and 30.8 %, respectively. The catalyst Co20MMO, after 270 min of reaction, started to increase the 1-butanol production reaching 36.5 %. For Cu20MMO 1-butanol production continuously increased reaching a maximum of 56 % of selectivity at 360 min. Although the observation of an increase in 1-butanol production could be interpreted as a positive characteristic, it is important to recall that both Co20MMO and Cu20MMO showed a decrease in ethanol consumption, as seen in Fig. 2. A second important product for GR is acetaldehyde which is a reaction intermediate for 1-butanol. For MMO and Zn20MMO, a plateau was reached with maximum selectivities of 15.7 and 23.5 % respectively. For Ni20MMO, the maximum selectivity was reached after 30 min and then continuously decreased until 330 min with a small increase at 360 min. Co20MMO presented oscillatory behavior, although with a tendency to decrease. For the Cu20MMO catalyst, the maximum of 25 % selectivity was reached after 120 min, then decreasing until 330 min, stabilizing at 8.1 % selectivity. Taking into account the reaction pathways shown in Fig. 1, diethyl ether and ethyl acetate can be considered unwanted products for GR. For diethyl ether, the temporal profiles for each catalyst changed regarding 1-butanol and acetaldehyde. Fe20MMO showed a constant increase reaching 32 % selectivity at 360 min while Co20MMO, Ni20MMO, Cu20MMO and Zn20MMO reached a plateau at distinct reactions times, with selectivities of 16.7, 25.9, 12.2 and 6.3 % respectively. For MMO, the diethyl ether reached a maximum of 40 % selectivity at 30 min of reaction and decreased until reaching a plateau at 19 %. Finally, regarding ethyl acetate, the selectivities for all catalysts were by far the lowest compared with the other three products. For MMO and Ni20MMO, almost no ethyl acetate was detected. Fe20MMO presented oscillatory behavior with selectivity ca. 2.8 %. For Co20MMO, Cu20MMO and Zn20MMO, a plateau was reached with selectivities of 4.8, 3.9 and 10.6 %, respectively. Taking into account the ethanol conversion and temporal behavior of 1-butanol, acetaldehyde, diethyl ether and ethyl acetate, it is possible to rank the catalysts in order of choice for GR. Ethanol conversion is time-stable for MMO, Ni20MMO and Zn20MMO, making the other three catalysts less attractive since the continuous loss of ethanol conversion impacts on the desired products (1-butanol and acetaldehyde) for GR. Thus, Fe20MMO, Co20MMO and Cu20MMO, even with good selectivities for the desired products in the temporal behavior analysis, would not be the best choice. Taking into account the temporal behavior of the products, MMO, Ni20MMO and Zn20MMO seem to be the best choices for GR because, apart from ethanol conversion, they presented high selectivities for 1-butanol and acetaldehyde and lower selectivities for the side products (diethyl ether and ethyl acetate). There was no correlation between the ethanol conversion and product selectivities with physicochemical catalyst properties such as acidity, basicity, acidity/basicity ratio. 3.4 Catalyst characterization after reaction After the catalytic assays, the materials were submitted to characterization by means of EPR, XRD, TGA, SEM and EDS, aiming to better understand the behavior of MMOs during the course of the reaction. The EPR analysis for the catalysts containing Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn presented a paramagnetic signal with g value around 2.0106 and linewidth ca. 6.0 G. For the reference material (MMO), the EPR spectrum was silent. For the Cu containing catalyst, the signal of Cu2+ was seen with g = 2.1532 and for the other metal ions, no signal was observed since the spectra were obtained at 25 °C. The g value and linewidth found were not coherent with paramagnetic transition metal ions [54]. Fig. 5 shows the EPR spectra for all catalysts after the reaction. Thus, the EPR signals mentioned above can only be correlated with oxygen vacancies (OV) in the catalyst structure during the ethanol reaction [54–58]. The OV can enhance the reactivity of the catalyst, since it is already reported that the catalyst basicity increases with the removal of oxygen from the surface [54,55]. Also, OV are related with oxidation reactions and strong interaction with carbonyl groups [54]. Using TGA analysis, the OV presented in the catalysts were quantified [59–61] (Fig. S4 and Table S9). As observed by EPR, MMO did not show the presence of OV. For the other catalysts, a mass gain ca. 690 °C, ranging from 0.20 to 0.75 % was observed. These values are in agreement with those for other metal oxides reported in the literature [60–62]. The OV may have an important role in ethanol dehydrogenation into acetaldehyde and may enhance the acetaldehyde reactivity in the aldol condensation, by its stabilization through the carbonyl group on the catalyst surface. On this matter, Li and co-workers established a linear relationship between the concentration of OV (ranging from 30 to 46 %) and yield of condensation products (butyraldehyde, crotonaldehyde among others) employing CeO2 with distinct morphologies and redox states [63]. However, it was not possible in our study to directly correlate the OV percentages in the MMOs and the condensation product yields. The presence of OV are also related to ethanol dehydration into ethylene [54]. Thus, OV may contribute to ambivalent behavior in the catalytic process. It may enhance the ethanol reactivity for the Guerbet reaction pathway and introduce a competitive reaction pathway (ethanol dehydration), diminishing the GR products. It is also important to recall that only the MMOs with transition metals in their structure presented OV. This behavior may be due to the enhancement of acidity due to the substitution of Mg2+ by the first-row transition metal ions, facilitating the removal of oxygen from the MMO surface. This hypothesis proved to be coherent since Fe20MMO and Cu20MMO, which had the highest and lowest acidity values (Table S2), also presented the highest and lowest OV concentrations, respectively. The MMOs were also characterized using XRD, aiming to follow any structural changes. After 6 h of reaction, all catalysts still presented the characteristic 3 peak pattern of the fresh catalysts (Fig. S5). However, calculating the crystallographic parameters (a: cation-cation distance; D: crystallite size) for all the catalysts, changes could be noticed. Table S10 resumes the parameters calculated for the catalysts. The crystallite size ( D ) increased for the Co20MMO, Ni20MMO and Cu20MMO (25, 12 and 16 % respectively) and this corroborates with the increase in the cation-cation distance ( a ). The increase of these two parameters indicates that during the reaction, the catalyst structure is modified in some way, promoting a relaxation in its structure. However, the absence of new peaks suggests that no phase segregation or redox reactions occurred in any extensive way. The MMO acidity and basicity values followed similar behavior; there was no clear correlation between the crystallographic parameters and the product distributions found. To complement the XRD analysis of MMO structures, TGA, SEM, and EDS analyses were also carried out. The TGA analysis of the catalysts showed thermal events in the temperature range from 300 to 700 °C. It is well-reported in the literature that carbon species are oxidized to CO and CO2 in this temperature range and it is possible to infer the type of carbon present in the samples (amorphous carbon ca. 250–400 °C, nanostructured materials like nanofibers and nanotubes ca. 400–700 °C) [64]. Thus, TGA and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of the MMOs after the reaction showed the deposition of two distinct types of carbon over the catalysts: amorphous and nanostructured, as seen in the thermograms of Figs. S6–S11. The percentage of carbon in each sample was determined, ranging from 9.5 to 36.4 % of the initial mass. Deconvoluting the DTA spectra and integrating the curves (Figs. S12–S17) determined the percentage of each type of carbon deposited on the MMOs. The amorphous carbon corresponds to the lower percentage found, ranging from 0.7 to 19.2 %, the nanostructured carbon corresponding to 80.8–99.3 % of the deposited carbon. Table S11 summarizes the data. SEM images showed the formation of clusters after the reaction, indicating that the catalytic process induces particle aggregation (Figs. S18–S23). Also, SEM images indicated filamentous carbon (CF) formation in the catalysts Fe20MMO, Co20MMO, Ni20MMO, and Cu20MMO. Surprisingly, MMO and Zn20MMO images did not display the formation of CF, corroborating with the lower percentage of carbon deposition found in TGA. The EDS analysis indicated carbon in all samples, although with much lower content for MMO and Zn20MMO catalysts (Table S12). The percentages of carbon found in EDS were very distinct from the ones found by TGA. This observation is coherent since EDS quantifies only spots of the sample, while TGA furnishes a complete panorama of the sample. Fig. 6 depicts the SEM for Ni20MMO before the reaction (A) and after 6 h of reaction (B) showing the CF The deposition of carbon species over catalysts is associated with CH4 and CO presence in the reaction medium and is usually found in catalytic approaches to the ethanol steam reforming reaction [37,39,41,65]. Although amorphous carbon deposition is associated with catalyst deactivation due to the blocking of active sites, CF is not associated directly with catalyst poisoning since the catalyst reaction sites are not blocked. However, over long operational periods, the continuous formation of CF can inactivate the catalyst because a sintering process at the catalyst active sites can be induced [37]. Also, there was no correlation of the MMO activity and the percentage of deposited carbon (amorphous or nanostructured). Thus, the TGA and SEM data indicated that, as expected, in our catalytic approach, a fraction of ethanol in the reactor undergoes a reforming reaction and CO and CH4 are transformed into carbon species since it is not possible to direct the ethanol reaction along the GR pathway only. As shown in Fig. 1, acetaldehyde is the key-intermediate for both GR and the ethanol reforming reaction yielding CH4 and CO. Thus, the carbon species formation is directly related to the catalyst ability to promote acetaldehyde decomposition (1), methane dehydrogenation (2) and the CO Boudouard reaction (3) [65]. Catalysts containing first-row transition metals, except Zn, were reported to be active in the ethanol steam reforming reaction and thus are expected to promote the carbon deposition by the pathways described above. 3.5 Catalyst efficiency for ethanol GR After the quantification of the GR products and catalyst characterization, mostly by the percentage of carbon deposition, these parameters can be correlated with the best catalyst choice for ethanol conversion into 1-butanol, which is the main goal of GR. However, not only the 1-butanol selectivity should be taken into account, but also the main side product formation (sum of diethyl ether and ethyl acetate) and the percentage of carbon deposition over the catalyst surface. Large amounts of side products diminish the 1-butanol selectivity and the separation process becomes more complicated, thinking forward to up-scaling. Also, the percentage of carbon deposition (amorphous or filamentous) will diminish the catalyst activity over time, demanding carbon removal from its surface or replacing the catalyst in the reactor. Aiming to rank the MMOs utilized as GR catalysts in the present study, four variables, ethanol conversion, 1-butanol selectivity, main side-product selectivities and the percentage of carbon deposition were compared, as shown in Fig. 7 . Notice that Fe20MMO, Co20MMO and Cu20MMO were excluded from the comparison, since these catalysts presented a drop in ethanol consumption over 6 h of reaction. Thus, taking into account the data of Fig. 7, Zn20MMO catalyst seems to be the best choice for GR. Although Ni20MMO presents a higher 1-butanol selectivity, Zn20MMO presented lower side product production and a considerably lower carbon deposition over the catalyst in 6 h of reaction. 3.6 Catalyst tailoring for ethanol GR The literature has also reported the role of transition metals in the catalytic growing of carbon nanotubes, related to the energy of the metal-carbon bond at the catalyst surface [66]. Thus, it was possible to establish a correlation between the percentage of carbon found in TGA analysis of the MMOs and the metal-carbon bond energy calculated for growing carbon nanotubes. Fig. 8 shows the correlation. As shown in Fig. 8, there is a clear linear relationship between carbon deposition in the catalyst and the first-row transition metals employed as dopant. The data obtained from TGA, SEM and EDS experiments indicate that the carbon deposition is an intrinsic process related to the affinity of carbon atoms to the transition metal present in the catalyst composition. Thus, the tailoring of catalysts aiming to better perform GR should consider this relationship. For example, the Ni-containing catalyst presented the best conversion of ethanol into 1-butanol but presented a high amount of CF formation. On the other hand, the Zn-containing catalyst produced 30 % less 1-butanol than the Ni-containing catalyst. Thus, for future catalyst development, it seems that a bimetallic catalyst with Ni-Zn could be the right candidate that associates both high ethanol conversion to 1-butanol and, also, a lower carbon deposition over the catalyst surface. It has already been reported in the literature that Zn addition to Cu [67–69], Pt-Sn [70], Pt [71], and Pd [72] catalysts enhance their stability and conversion rate, as well as changing the product distribution for the water-gas shift [67], hydrogenation [68], methanol steam reforming [69], and dehydrogenation [70–72] reactions. However, until now, there was no clear correlation between the Zn-promoted catalytic enhancing capacity and carbon deposition over the surface, although it has already been shown that Zn-containing catalysts diminished the carbon deposition [71]. Thus, the correlation presented in Fig. 8 helps to explain the behavior of Zn-containing catalysts. 4 Conclusions A series of MMOs containing Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ were tested as catalysts for GR in a fixed bed flow reactor. Considering the ethanol conversion, GR products, side products, and carbon deposition over the catalyst surface in 6 h of reaction, the catalyst containing Zn presented the best results. Although the Ni-containing catalyst produced a higher quantity of 1-butanol, the high deposition of CF over the catalyst surface may be a drawback in future applications. A correlation between the percentage of deposited carbon and the metal-carbon bond energy was established. This relationship, along with the catalysis results, can be useful in tailoring new catalysts for GR. Bimetallic catalysts containing Zn would be a starting point since Zn presented a low-carbon deposition, and its combination with other transition metals may enhance its reactivity and selectivity for GR products. coredata.dc:description: Described is the transformation of ethanol into 1-butanol, acetaldehyde and other products by the Guerbet reaction (GR) over mixed metal oxides (MMOs) as catalysts. The MMOs, in which Mg2+ was partially (20 mol%) substituted by Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+, were obtained from hydrotalcite precursors and the reactions conducted in a fixed bed flow reactor. EPR was used to observe oxygen vacancies after the catalytic reactions, which may be related to the ethanol reactivity due to the basicity enhancement of the catalyst. Carbon deposition, mostly filamentous, was observed in all catalysts and a trend between the metal-carbon bond energy and the percentage of deposited carbon was established. This correlation and the catalyst product distribution can be useful to tailor new catalysts. Using four parameters, ethanol conversion, 1-butanol and side-product selectivities and percentage of carbon deposition, Zn20MMO proved to be the best choice for GR.
coredata.dc:title: First row transition metals on the ethanol Guerbet reaction: Products distribution and structural behavior of mixed metal oxides as catalysts
